dict.string: She was born Maria Sklodowska in 1867 in Warsaw, Poland, as the youngest of five children in her family.
Raised by a Catholic mother and an atheist father, she became agnostic after her mother's death.
Along with her husband, she discovered two different elements, Polonium and Radium in the same year.
She was the only person to win Nobel Prizes in different fields, one in Physics and another one in Chemistry.
In her early research with uranium, she showed that atoms were divisible, which led to the creation of atomic physics.
Instead of wearing a bridal grown, she worn a dark blue dress, which served her for many years as a laboratory outfit.
She died of aplastic anemia due to prolonged exposure to radiation, but she never acknowledged the health risks of it.
Her passion for science was inspired by her father, a physics teacher who showed his children his lab equipment.
Her husband Pierre researched magnetism, but a contemporary quipped that his greatest discovery was Marie.
To afford university tuition and living expense, she studied during the day and worked as a tutor in the evening.
Prohibited from higher education in her native country because she was a woman, she moved to Paris where she got a PhD.
Her work-related papers are highly radioactive, and those who wish to consult them must wear protective clothing.
